text: The instant I broke from the shield wall, the world felt like it had been twisted into a single knot of wind and snow. The edge of a shield scraped my shoulder—iron grinding against ice with a shriek that cut through the storm.

The snow beneath my feet had been softened by the Demon King’s ‘breathing,’ as if it could collapse into a sinkhole at any moment. A jagged stone heaved up and nearly tripped me, but I forced that step down and held.
I knew I wasn’t running out to kill it. I only had to steal half a second—rip it out from between the black mist’s teeth.
I swallowed air into my lungs like I was swallowing my fear. Then I hurled my voice out—harder than the wind.
“Alicia—! No matter how many times, I will wait for you!”
The wind tore at the words, but they didn’t break. They drew tight like a taut line and hooked straight into her chest.
Alicia’s fingers had been shaking—fatigue crashing down like an old wound flaring up. But the moment my voice landed, her knuckles steadied, just a fraction.
The Demon King heard it too. Its black mist faltered—an instant, as if someone had yanked its tail.
The Demon King tilted its head. Not in rage—more like confusion. As if, for the first time, it realized there was a ‘variable’ inside the loop.
In that half second, the black mist coiled around Alicia’s wrist loosened by a single thread.
Alicia’s voice came out hoarse, but there was a smile in it: “…Don’t do anything stupid.”
She didn’t look back at me. With that short sentence, she pinned me in place—part command, part protection.
Then she moved. Not faster—sharper. She aligned her body with the loosened flow of the mist, turning that ‘gap’ into a ‘path.’
With a flick of her wrist, the necklace slid out from inside her cloak. The pendant burned bright in the black light, and she gripped it like she would never let go.
The mist tried to surge back, like a tide turning to bite. But the Demon King’s attention was still nailed in place by my voice—it was half a beat too slow.
Half a beat is the difference between life and death.
Alicia whispered, “End it.”
She rammed the necklace into the裂 in the core. The moment the pendant vanished into the black light, the core ignited—light swelling outward from within.
The Demon King let out a distorted scream. Its bone armor split, cracks crawling up into the sky.
Alicia wrenched her sword free and retreated, then took a step toward me—like she was finally allowing herself to admit she wasn’t alone.
But it was already too late.
Behind her, the core collapsed in on itself, like the world drawing in a breath.
The explosion’s shockwave burst outward. Snow and shattered stone rose into a white tide; the city wall itself trembled. Alicia was thrown violently through the air, slamming toward me.
In midair she twisted, turning her back to the blast—like pure instinct choosing to take the worst of the storm for me.
She hit the ground hard beside me. Her shoulder guard broke apart, her breath stuttered—yet she still reached out to make sure I was there.
I coughed out a breath, my voice shaking: “You… you did it…”
At the heart of the blast, the Demon King’s shape was coming apart. Black mist fell away like shredded curtains, peeling into the rift.
At last, the Demon King vanished completely. The rift looked as if it had been forcibly stitched shut, the luminous patterns in the sky fading piece by piece.
The wind stopped. That suffocating sense of a countdown stopped with it.
